Award.AwardTitle: Creation of POLS-SAVI Node at the University of Maryland
Award.AbstractNarration:
Project: This is a project to create a POLS-SAVI node at the University of Maryland (UMD). This node, which was conceived during the early stages of the newly created Student Research Network and is vastly expanded under Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) initiative, will also bring in two leading institutions. One is the Technical University of Munich (TUM), which is one of the leading centers in Biophysics in Germany. The other is the National Center for Biological Sciences (NCBS) in India, which enjoys a preeminent stature in the biophysics in the country. These three institutions will add greatly to the POLS-SAVI network both in scientific expertise as well as in the educational aspects. The faculty in the three institutions who will join the POLS-SAVI network bring to bear expertise in a number of areas in biological physics. Among the faculty there is considerable expertise in the basics of equilibrium and non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, which are becoming increasingly important in tackling problems in single molecule force spectroscopy, a tool that is being used to discover the role of mechanical forces in biology. Methods in these areas are key in understanding fluctuation effects in finite systems including various metabolic and gene networks. On the experimental side both in TUM and UMD a variety of problems probing the response of forces from single molecule to cellular level are being performed using a variety of techniques. Research is also being carried out to understand interactions between proteins and how such interactions are involved in signaling networks. The three universities also focus on functions of molecular machines, mechanics of cytoskeletal networks, the role of membranes in biological functions, and gene networks. Thus, from a scientific perspective UMD, TUM, and NCBS are involved in researches covering the gamut of temporal and length scales. These topics add to and enhance the scope of issues that are being covered by other participating institutions. All three institutions are also deeply involved in educating students in this new emerging area. The collective experience gathered in the three continents will also be useful as the institutions in the network prepare to develop new curriculum. The major scientific benefit of leveraging the entire resources of the network will enable the participants to vastly expand their ability to conduct research by learning from the expertise available in the network rather than be limited by the tools available in one's home institution. In addition, the proposed video conferencing throughout the year between the students and the annual meeting in different venues add to invaluable educational experience in enhancing the scope of training in the POLS. Third, the international scope of the proposed network will have a world-wide impact on the scientific aspect by fostering many potentially powerful collaborations. The three institutions will aid in achieving the basic mission of the POLS-SAVI network, which in turn will have substantial impact on the development, use and application of quantitative methods in biological problems.

This project is being supported jointly by the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Physics Division and by the Molecular Biophysics Program in Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major objective of this network is to have students from through out the work interact, exchange ideas, and potentially initiate new projects focussing on the use of physics principles to solve biological problems. Right from the start the goal was to integrate the efforts at many centers so that the students from various universities would actively participate in a broad range of topics. The University of Maryland, College Park (UMCP) played a central role in this endeavor. During the entire period many nascent collaborations involving several universities in very diverse areas of biological physics began. Some of these are ongoing, and likely to bear fruit in the future.

Intellectual Impacts: The highlights of this network are the annual meeting showcasing the works of few PIs and the works of students in an informal setting. UMCP was fortunate to organize one near the NSF center. Typically, there about two hundred participants at these meetings. The one in the Washington area, that UMCP hosted, attracted scientists from South America, Israel, France, United States,  and Germany. Like all other meetings (held in Princeton, Yale, Harvard, Munich, and Paris) this was a resounding success. Remarkably, without much, if any hekp from the PIs the junior scientists naturally exchange scientific ideas. There have been some joint publications through this network, and it is anticipated that more will come.

Yet another highlight of this network, which is likely to increase with time, are the mini cources that have been offered on different topics (for example cancer and protein folding) that brought many key scientists and students together. The experiences of students participating from UMCP was uniformly fantastic.

Broader Impacr: It cannot go unstated that this program brings a lot for buck, and its efficacy and impact is likely to grow in directions that one cannot anticipate. As the impact of physics biology continues to increase so will the effect of this network, which brings into contact scientists from vastly different fields together. The meetings, which have taken place in metropolitan areas wuth nearby academic institutions, usually draws unexpected visitors. This has the added benefit that such visitors, with experise in areas beyond physics, bring new [erspective. By the same token they are enriched as well, thus enhancing the broader impact of the program. This has been evident in all the meetings including the most recent meeting in PParis (June, 2017). 

Although one could improve the scope of the Physics of Living System network more it is abundantly clear that even at this stage it is like a microversion of CERN, the center where the largest high energy experiments are conducted. The POLS network will likely be a similar symbol for the physics of living systems.
